title: North Norfolk Coast biosphere reserve
text:
Situated north of <a href="Norwich">Norwich</a> on the <a href="Norfolk">Norfolk</a> coast, the North Norfolk Coast <a href="biosphere%20reserve">biosphere reserve</a> was a biosphere reserve until 2014 when its status was withdrawn. The area includes a wide range of habitats, from <a href="Intertidal%20zone">intertidal</a> sands and muds, through <a href="shingle%20beach">shingle</a> ridges, to <a href="Brackish%20water">saltwater</a> and <a href="Fresh%20water">freshwater</a> marshes. The <a href="Salt%20marsh">saltmarshes</a> are of great value for breeding and wintering <a href="wildfowl">wildfowl</a> and includes a large breeding colony of <a href="common%20seals">common seals</a>. Other habitats comprise <a href="mire">mire</a>s, <a href="river%20valley">river valley</a>s, <a href="heath">heath</a>lands, chalk and cliff-top grasslands, woodlands and farmland.
Many tourists frequent the area, notably for beach activities and birdwatching. There arises some pressure on specific sites due to these activities. Other activities within the biosphere reserve are the cultivation of mainly <a href="cereal">cereal</a>s and <a href="sugar%20beet">sugar beet</a>, grazing and harvesting <a href="mussel">mussel</a>s, <a href="cockle%20%28bivalve%29">cockle</a>s, <a href="shrimp">shrimp</a>s, <a href="crab">crab</a>s, and <a href="Fishing%20bait">bait</a> as well as some commercial shore-netting. Educational visits of school children and students take place and there are a number of interpretive and field centres in the area. Research covers a full range of biological sciences (and especially <a href="ornithology">ornithology</a>), and also relates to the <a href="geomorphology">geomorphology</a> of coastal processes.
